10.1145/3184558.3188728.title: Misleading or Falsification: Inferring Deceptive Strategies and Types in Online News and Social Media
10.1145/3184558.3188728.author: Volkova, Svitlana and Jang, Jin Yea
10.1145/3184558.3188728.paperMotivationText: Deceptive information in online news and social media has had dramatic effect on our society in recent years. Detecting and understanding it is thus crucial.
10.1145/3184558.3188728.paperContributionText: The authors analyze psycholinguistic signals (moral foundations and connotations) in deceptive news. They build models for the detection of deception strategies using biased language markers, moral foundations and connotations.
10.1145/3184558.3188728.paperResultsText: The proposed model performs well compared to previous models that rely on syntactic and stylistic markers. Falsification strategy is easier to identify than misleading strategy. Disinformation is more difficult to predict than to propaganda or hoaxes. Deceptive news types are easier to identify in tweets than in news reports.
